user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_softirq_dispatch:
```c
void metal_softirq_dispatch(void)
{
	int i;

	for (i = 0; i < metal_softirq_num; i++) {
		struct metal_irq *irq;
		char is_pending = 1;

		if (atomic_load(&metal_softirq_enabled[i]) != 0 &&
		    atomic_compare_exchange_strong(&metal_softirq_pending[i],
						   &is_pending, 0)) {
			irq = &metal_softirqs[i];
			(void)metal_irq_handle(irq,
					       i + metal_softirq_cntr.irq_base);
		}
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
atomic_load(&metal_softirq_enabled[i])
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the C11 atomic_load function takes a pointer to a const-qualified atomic object, so passing &metal_softirq_enabled[i] converts to the required const-qualified parameter. There is no pointer variable here that should be const-qualified but is not. A violation would occur if the API required a non-const pointer or if the code stored the address into a non-const pointer when a pointer-to-const could be used (e.g. assigning &metal_softirq_enabled[i] to a non-const pointer instead of a pointer-to-const).
